content:
Funny how you chose the symbols for the operators! For shortest mode they have an interesting property:
If `c` is a character in `"+-x/^"`, then the ASCII value of `c`, taken modulo 6, is in [0,1,3,4,5], and can be used as an index in a list of possible results.

Nice clash, but Validator 7 here is a really hard edge case that's not tested in the test cases. It's annoying cos you get 100% on tests, then 85% on submission if you can't deal with it.

The issue is that early on you get 1581**-2, which in Ruby evaluates to "4.0007025233631027e-07", which is the only time that scientific notation ends up coming into the tests. It's really hard to manage this using Regex, even in the IDE, let alone when you don't know it's going to come up in a validator. It would be good to either simplify Validator 7 to remove this, or add a test case that has a similar issue, so clashers can debug in-clash.

You should change those sentences because it is quite disturbing :
In the goal section, you write : "The result of the calculation must be rounded down to the nearest integer.". And in the "output" section, you write "Integer: result of the calculation rounded to the nearest integer."
If we follow the "output" section, "rounded to the nearest integer" does NOT mean "rounded down" but really "rounded to the nearest integer". (function round() and NOT floor() or int)
I suggest you to clarify those two sentences by writing"result of the calculation rounded down"

Goal section
* In the example, the operators (-, +) in a different order from the calculation (1 + 2 - 3 and not 1 - 2 + 3).

Thanks.
Oops, thanks! I had it first on rounded, and then shifted to rounded down, thanks for finding where I forgot to change it.
Hmm that edge case was totally unintended. Can you share your ruby code with me so that I can make a simplification and check whether it was simplified enough?

Sure:

n = gets.to_i
s = integers = gets.chomp
o = operators = gets.tr("x","*").gsub("^","**").gsub("/",".0/").split
e = s.gsub(" "){o.shift}
warn n,s,o,e
while e[/[^-\d\.]/]
  e.sub!(/-?\d+\.?\d*\D+\d+\.?\d*/){eval _1}
  warn e
end
puts eval(e).to_i

ok, thanks for sharing, I think I resolved it (changed one of the ^ into +).

I don't know ruby, but I assume .to_i does the same as int() in python? Then I am surprised this problem comes up. int(some_scientific_notation) would just result in an integer if I am not mistaken.

And apologies for breaking your streak - I assume at least that a top-20 COC player is used to continuous 100% scores in a row, so this one would annoy you.

Thanks a bunch. :)

.to_i is the same as int(), yeah. But the problem is that I only call .to_i at the end, the scientific notation comes up before the remaining operations are resolved, so my Regex needed to account for the fact that "e-07" can be part of a float in order to parse the sub-equations for solving left-to-right. I'd assumed that numbers should always look like /-?\d+\.?\d*/, but to account for that validator I ended up needing something much for complicated.

Haha, I'm flattered. ^_^ I really have my win streaks broken quite a lot honestly (*side-eyes comp0zr*), but I ended up coming last in that clash, so it was painful as you thought, haha. In the end it was my fault for relying on RegEx for a calculation based challenge. It works well for similar clashes where the input is a single equation you have to solve left-to-right, but since you give the operands as an array here, RegEx was not really a smart way to solve it.

I also got 100% on the tests but 85% on the validators.

My issue was with validator 6, where my python program crashed with OverflowError: (34, 'Numerical result out of range')

I was in Shortest Mode, here is my code:
_,N,O=open(0)
t,*X=map(int,N.split())
for x,o in zip(X,O.split()):t=(t*x,t+x,0,t-x,t**x,x and t/x)[ord(o)%6]
print(int(t))

My mistake was in not noticing that some tests had negative numbers on the first line (I was sure it was only natural integers). And computing t**x when x is negative can be a problem.
